Dosage: treatment 200 to 300 mg/kg/day divided every 4 to 6 hours; maximum daily dose: 12 g/day
renal_adjustment_dose: GFR 30 to 50 mL/minute/1.73 m2: 35 to 50 mg/kg/dose every 6 hours
Administration: IV push: Doses ≤500 mg should be administered over 3 to 5 minutes; doses >500 mg should be administered over 10 to 15 minutes; rapid administration has been associated with seizures.    Intermittent IV infusion: Infuse over 10 to 15 minutes
Preparation_for_administration:
Reconstitute vial with the following amounts of SWFI or bacteriostatic water for injection  25 mg, 250 mg, or 500 mg vials: 5 mL; final concentration will vary depending on vial size.

1,000 mg vial: 7.4 mL.

2,000 mg vial: 14.8 mL.  further dilute for infusion; NS is the diluent of choice for intermittent infusion  Final concentration should not exceed 30 mg/mL

Dosage: treatment:  200 to 300 mg ampicillin/kg/day divided every 4 to 6 hours; maximum dose: 2,000 mg ampicillin/dose.
renal_adjustment_dose: CrCl ≥30 mL/minute/1.73 m2: No dosage adjustment required
Administration: IV: Administer by slow IV injection over 10 to 15 minutes or by intermittent IV infusion over 15 to 30 minutes.
Preparation_for_administration: Single-dose vials: Reconstitute 1.5 g vial with 3.2 mL SWFI or 3 g vial with 6.4 mL SWFI; resultant concentration: 375 mg/mL of total ampicillin/sulbactam (ie, 250 mg/mL of ampicillin and 125 mg/mL of sulbactam). Further dilute with a compatible solution to a final concentration of 3 to 45 mg/mL of total ampicillin/sulbactam (2 to 30 mg/mL of ampicillin and 1 to 15 mg/mL of sulbactam).

Dosage: acute retinal necrosis, treatment (patients with HIV): 10 to 15 mg/kg/dose every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days.
renal_adjustment_dose: CrCl >50 mL/minute/1.73 m2: IV: No dosage adjustment necessary (Ref).
Administration: Parenteral: Administer by slow IV infusion over at least 1 hour; rapid infusion is associated with nephrotoxicity due to crystalluria and renal tubular damage and should be avoided. Maintain adequate hydration during therapy.
Preparation_for_administration: Parenteral: IV: Dilute in a compatible solution (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration ≤7 mg/mL.

Dosage: acute retinal necrosis, treatment (patients with HIV): 10 to 15 mg/kg/dose every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days.
renal_adjustment_dose: CrCl 25 to 50 mL/minute/1.73 m2: IV: Administer the usual recommended dose every 12 hours (Ref).
Administration: Parenteral: Administer by slow IV infusion over at least 1 hour; rapid infusion is associated with nephrotoxicity due to crystalluria and renal tubular damage and should be avoided. Maintain adequate hydration during therapy.

Drug_class: Blood Product Derivative; Plasma Volume Expander, Colloid
Dosage: 25% albumin: IV: 0.5 to 1 g/kg/dose over 2 to 3 hours; may repeat up to 3 times per day until albumin is >2.5 g/dL; maximum dose: 25 g/dose
renal_adjustment_dose: There are no dosing adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling; use with caution.
Administration: 25%: Do not exceed 1 to 2 mL/minute in patients without shock
Preparation_for_administration: Parenteral: IV: If 5% human albumin is unavailable, it may be prepared by diluting 25% human albumin with NS or D5W (if sodium load is a concern). Do not use sterile water to dilute albumin solutions, as this has been associated with hypotonic-associated hemolysis.
Storage_Stability: Store at ≤25°C (≤77°F); do not freeze. Do not use solution if it is turbid or contains a deposit; use within 4 hours after opening vial; discard unused portion.

Drug_class: Blood Product Derivative; Plasma Volume Expander, Colloid
Dosage: 25% albumin: IV: 0.5 to 1 g/kg/dose over 30 to 60 minutes followed by diuretic
renal_adjustment_dose: There are no dosing adjustments provided in the manufacturer's labeling; use with caution.
Administration: 25%: Do not exceed 1 to 2 mL/minute in patients without shock
Preparation_for_administration: Parenteral: IV: If 5% human albumin is unavailable, it may be prepared by diluting 25% human albumin with NS or D5W (if sodium load is a concern). Do not use sterile water to dilute albumin solutions, as this has been associated with hypotonic-associated hemolysis.
Storage_Stability: Store at ≤25°C (≤77°F); do not freeze. Do not use solution if it is turbid or contains a deposit; use within 4 hours after opening vial; discard unused portion.

Dosage: :  Loading dose: 5 mg/kg (maximum dose: 300 mg/dose) over 20 to 60 minutes; may repeat twice up to maximum total dose of 15 mg/kg during acute treatment
renal_adjustment_dose: For infusions >1 hour, use concentrations ≤2 mg/mL unless a central venous catheter is used; commercially prepared premixed solutions in concentrations of 1.5 mg/mL and 1.8 mg/mL are available. Use only volumetric infusion pump; use of drop counting may lead to underdosage. Administer through an IV line located as centrally as possible. For peripheral infusions, an in-line filter has been recommended during administration to reduce the incidence of phlebitis (consult individual institutional policies and procedures). During pulseless VT/VF, administering undiluted is preferred
Administration: Information based on adult data: Injection must be diluted before IV use. Administer via central venous catheter, if possible; increased phlebitis may occur with peripheral infusions >3 mg/mL in D5W; the use of a central venous catheter with concentrations >2 mg/mL for infusions >1 hour is recommended. Must be infused via volumetric infusion device; drop size of IV solution may be reduced and underdosage may occur if drop counter-infusion sets are used. PVC tubing is recommended for administration regardless of infusion duration. Incompatible with heparin; flush with normal saline prior to and following infusion.
Preparation_for_administration: Continuous IV infusion: Information based on adult data: Injection must be diluted in D5W to maximum concentration for IV infusion of 6 mg/mL prior to administration. Commercially prepared premixed solutions in concentrations of 1.5 mg/mL and 1.8 mg/mL are available. ASHP recommends standard concentrations of 1.8 mg/mL and 3.6 mg/mL in pediatric patients
Storage_Stability: Injection: Store undiluted vials and premixed solutions (Nexterone) at 20°C to 25°C (68°F to 77°F); excursions are permitted between 15°C and 30°C

Dosage: Loading dose: IV: 5 mg/kg (maximum dose: 300 mg/dose) given over 60 minutes   Continuous IV infusion (if needed): Dosing based on mcg/kg/minute: Initial: 5 mcg/kg/minute; increase incrementally as clinically needed; range: 5 to 15 mcg/kg/minute; maximum daily dose: 2,200 mg/day .  Dosing based on mg/kg/day: Initial: 10 mg/kg/day; increase incrementally as clinically needed; range: 10 to 20 mg/kg/day; maximum daily dose: 2,200 mg/day .
renal_adjustment_dose: For infusions >1 hour, use concentrations ≤2 mg/mL unless a central venous catheter is used; commercially prepared premixed solutions in concentrations of 1.5 mg/mL and 1.8 mg/mL are available. Use only volumetric infusion pump; use of drop counting may lead to underdosage. Administer through an IV line located as centrally as possible. For peripheral infusions, an in-line filter has been recommended during administration to reduce the incidence of phlebitis (consult individual institutional policies and procedures). During pulseless VT/VF, administering undiluted is preferred
Administration: Perfusing arrhythmias: Information based on adult data: Injection must be diluted before IV use. Administer via central venous catheter, if possible; increased phlebitis may occur with peripheral infusions >3 mg/mL in D5W; the use of a central venous catheter with concentrations >2 mg/mL for infusions >1 hour is recommended. Must be infused via volumetric infusion device; drop size of IV solution may be reduced and underdosage may occur if drop counter-infusion sets are used. PVC tubing is recommended for administration regardless of infusion duration. Incompatible with heparin; flush with normal saline prior to and following infusion.
Preparation_for_administration: IV: Perfusing arrhythmias: Continuous IV infusion: Information based on adult data: Injection must be diluted in D5W to maximum concentration for IV infusion of 6 mg/mL prior to administration. Commercially prepared premixed solutions in concentrations of 1.5 mg/mL and 1.8 mg/mL are available. ASHP recommends standard concentrations of 1.8 mg/mL and 3.6 mg/mL in pediatric patients
Storage_Stability: Injection: Store undiluted vials and premixed solutions (Nexterone) at 20°C to 25°C (68°F to 77°F); excursions are permitted between 15°C and 30°C

Dosage: 20 to 40 mg/kg/day divided every 6 to 8 hours  maximum daily dose: 2,700 mg/day
renal_adjustment_dose: Mild to severe impairment: No dosage adjustment necessary.
Administration: IV: Infuse over at least 10 to 60 minutes, at a rate not to exceed 30 mg/minute; hypotension and cardiopulmonary arrest have been reported following rapid IV administration.
Preparation_for_administration: Dilute vials that require dilution (150 mg/mL) with a compatible diluent (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration ≤18 mg/mL.

Dosage: IV: 25 to 40 mg/kg/day in divided doses every 8 hours; maximum dose: 600 mg/dose .
renal_adjustment_dose: Mild to severe impairment: No dosage adjustment necessary.
Administration: IV: Infuse over at least 10 to 60 minutes, at a rate not to exceed 30 mg/minute; hypotension and cardiopulmonary arrest have been reported following rapid IV administration.
Preparation_for_administration: Dilute vials that require dilution (150 mg/mL) with a compatible diluent (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration ≤18 mg/mL.

Dosage: 10 to 13 mg/kg/dose every 8 hours as part of an appropriate combination regimen in addition to surgical intervention; maximum dose: 900 mg/dose. Continue until further debridement is not necessary, patient has clinically improved, and patient is afebrile for 48 to 72 hours
renal_adjustment_dose: Mild to severe impairment: No dosage adjustment necessary.
Administration: IV: Infuse over at least 10 to 60 minutes, at a rate not to exceed 30 mg/minute; hypotension and cardiopulmonary arrest have been reported following rapid IV administration.
Preparation_for_administration: Dilute vials that require dilution (150 mg/mL) with a compatible diluent (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration ≤18 mg/mL.

Dosage:
IV: Initial: 60 mg/kg/day divided every 6 hours; initial maximum daily dose: 2,000 mg/day   

Children ≥12 years and Adolescents: IV: Initial: 60 to 70 mg/kg/day in divided doses every 6 to 8 hours; initial maximum daily dose: 3,600 mg/day.
renal_adjustment_dose: GFR 30 to 50 mL/minute/1.73 m2: 10 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours.
Administration: Intermittent infusion: Administer intermittent IV infusion over 60 minutes. Vancomycin infusion reaction (formerly "red man syndrome") may occur if the infusion is too rapid. It is not an allergic reaction, but may be characterized by hypotension and/or a maculopapular rash appearing on the face, neck, trunk, and/or upper extremities; if this should occur, slow the infusion rate to administer dose over 90 to 120 minutes (Ref) and increase the dilution volume; the reaction usually dissipates in 30 to 60 minutes; administration of antihistamines just before the infusion may also prevent or minimize this reaction.     Continuous infusion: After loading dose, administer over 24 hours      Vancomycin is an irritant; ensure proper needle or catheter placement prior to and during infusion. Avoid extravasation. If extravasation occurs, stop infusion immediately; leave cannula/needle in place temporarily but do NOT flush the line; gently aspirate extravasated solution, then remove needle/cannula; elevate extremity. Information varies regarding the use of dry cold or dry warm compresses; however, dry warm compresses may be of benefit in increasing local blood flow to enhance drug removal from the extravasation site (Ref). Hyaluronidase may be considered for refractory cases
Preparation_for_administration: Reconstitution: Single-dose vials (500 to 2,000 mg): Reconstitute with SWFI to a final concentration of 50 mg/mL. Further dilution is needed prior to administration with a compatible diluent (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration ≤5 mg/mL.

Children ≥12 years and Adolescents: IV: Initial: 60 to 70 mg/kg/day in divided doses every 6 to 8 hours; initial maximum daily dose: 3,600 mg/day.

Indication: Osteoarticular infection (eg, bacterial arthritis, osteomyelitis), acute

Dosage: Infants: IV: 6 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours; transition to oral valganciclovir (when able) to complete total treatment duration of 6 months    Cytomegalovirus infection, CNS; treatment:  Induction therapy (initial treatment): IV: 5 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours until symptoms improve; follow with chronic maintenance therapy  Chronic maintenance therapy (secondary prophylaxis): 5 mg/kg/dose once daily until patient has been receiving antiretroviral therapy for ≥6 months and achieves CD4 cell count targets for at least 6 months
renal_adjustment_dose: no pediatric-specific recommendations
Administration: Administer by slow IV infusion over at least 1 hour; infusing too rapidly can cause increased toxicity due to excessive plasma levels. Flush line well with NS before and after administration.
Preparation_for_administration: Powder for reconstitution: Reconstitute 500 mg vial with 10 mL SWFI (do not use bacteriostatic water; parabens may cause precipitation). Gently swirl the vial to dissolve. Further dilute in compatible diluent (eg, D5W, NS) to a final concentration of ≤10 mg/mL.

Dosage:
(eg, ventricular arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, supraventricular tachycardia, junctional ectopic tachycardia):  Loading dose (acute treatment):
1 mg/kg/dose over 30 to 60 minutes   Maintenance dose :   mg/kg/day divided every 8 to 12 hours
renal_adjustment_dose: Initiate at a lower dose and increase dose less frequently; allow adequate time between dosage increases to achieve new steady-state plasma concentration, since half-life will be prolonged. Closely monitor clinical response, heart rate, and QTc interval
Administration: Loading dose (acute treatment): Must be diluted prior to administration; administer over 15 to 60 minutes   Maintenance dose (unable to take oral medications): Must be diluted prior to administration; administer over 2 to 5 hours
Preparation_for_administration: Parenteral: Dilute in NS, D5W, or LR
